title: Clinical Reasoning in Assessment and Therapy Planning for Older Persons with Dysphagia - Intermediate | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Deepens skills in advanced clinical reasoning, assessment, and treatment of swallowing disorders in older persons through simulations and case discussions.

Clinical Reasoning in Assessment and Therapy Planning for Older Persons with Dysphagia - Intermediate
Clinical Reasoning in Assessment and Therapy Planning for Older Persons with Dysphagia - Intermediate
Deepens skills in advanced clinical reasoning, assessment, and treatment of swallowing disorders in older persons through simulations and case discussions.
This workshop is designed as an extension of the
Clinical Reasoning in Assessment and Therapy Planning for Older Persons with Dysphagia – Basic
. Learners must have completed the basic workshop if they choose to attend this workshop.

This workshop focuses on honing speech-language therapists’ clinical reasoning skills through case discussions and simulated patient scenarios, particularly those involving common conditions in older persons.

Learners will demonstrate their skills in dysphagia assessment by engaging in case scenarios and role play. This includes the practice of assessment techniques such as clinical observations, case history interviews, and more in-depth interpretation of instrumental assessments such as videofluoroscopy and fiberoptic endoscopic studies. Through interactive case discussions, learners will also practice integrating information to address how various medical conditions and comorbidities can influence the assessment and management of older persons with dysphagia.

Treatment approaches and interventions will be a key focus, with learners demonstrating their ability to manage dysphagia using various therapeutic strategies and interventions in both case discussions and simulated scenarios. Effective communication skills will be emphasised, particularly in counselling, education, and support related to dysphagia management.

As interdisciplinary collaboration is essential for comprehensive care, learners will participate in simulated team discussions where they will practice communicating important assessment and management issues with other healthcare professionals, such as physicians, nurses, and other allied health professionals.

The workshop will also cover ethical and legal considerations relevant to working with older persons, allowing learners to demonstrate their understanding of these principles through case discussions. It will also focus on developing skills in evidence-based practice, enabling learners to critically evaluate current research and guidelines to ensure informed decision-making and adherence to best practices in geriatric dysphagia.
Speech-language therapists who are conditionally registered and are working with older adults, or
Speech-language therapists who are currently working with a different client population and will be transitioning to work with older adults in the near future
"Clinical Reasoning in Assessment and Therapy Planning for Older Persons with Dysphagia - Basic"
By the end of the workshop, learners will be able to:

Develop skills in performing comprehensive clinical assessments of swallowing in older persons with dysphagia, including case information gathering, case history taking, clinical assessment, and interpretation and diagnosis
Acquire skills to implement various therapeutic interventions to manage dysphagia in older persons

Demonstrate the ability to provide counselling and education to older persons and their families, offering guidance on safe swallowing techniques, dietary modifications, and strategies for maintaining optimal oral health
Discuss and communicate the ethical considerations and legal frameworks relevant to working with older persons, including issues of consent, advocacy, and confidentiality

Develop the ability to critically evaluate and apply current research and evidence-based practice guidelines in the field of geriatric dysphagia, fostering a commitment to lifelong learning and professional development in their clinical practice
Senior Speech Therapist, National University Hospital
Senior Speech Therapist, National University Hospital

Calvin is a Speech Therapist working across both inpatient acute and outpatient adult settings. He holds a Master in Speech Language Pathology from University of Sydney, as well as a Master of Science in Health Professions Education with the University of Maastricht, in collaboration with Academy of Medicine Singapore.

He currently co-leads the adult Speech Therapy workgroup in NUH as well as lead education efforts. He has a keen interest in clinical education for both students and staff, as well as mentoring clinicians in their development as educators.
Principal Speech Therapist, Changi General Hospital
Principal Speech Therapist, Changi General Hospital

Yan Qing is a Speech Therapist working in Changi General Hospital. Her clinical interests include working with Geriatric patients, as well as in Voice Rehabilitation. She holds a Bachelor of Speech Pathology (Hons) from La Trobe University, Australia.
A Certificate of Participation will be issued to participants who
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course
The full fee for this course is S$2,725.00.
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.

Improving Patient Outcomes through Advanced Clinical Supervision Competency

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) taps on evidence-based education practices to address the increasing demand for advanced clinical supervision competencies among Allied Health Professionals and improve patient outcomes.

With the ageing population in Singapore, there has been a paradigm shift from structured institutionalised care to a more person-centric approach.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Design Innovation
As Singapore's ageing population continues to grow, care for the elderly is becoming a pressing issue.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation
Mobility, Balance & Falls in Older Adults: Symposium

With an average life expectancy of 83 in 2015, Singapore has the third-highest life expectancy in the world. For healthcare providers, an ageing population is associated with many issues, among which are falls in older persons.

This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) taps on evidence-based education practices to address the increasing demand for advanced clinical supervision competencies among Allied Health Professionals and improve patient outcomes.
With the ageing population in Singapore, there has been a paradigm shift from structured institutionalised care to a more person-centric approach.
As Singapore's ageing population continues to grow, care for the elderly is becoming a pressing issue.

With an average life expectancy of 83 in 2015, Singapore has the third-highest life expectancy in the world. For healthcare providers, an ageing population is associated with many issues, among which are falls in older persons.
This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.
This course equips occupational therapists with skills in occupational therapy-centric cognitive-perceptual assessments, problem identification, goal setting, and intervention plans.
Learn and develop skills in advanced clinical reasoning, assessment, and treatment of swallowing issues in older persons.
This module develops competencies in research design, critical appraisal, and ethical behaviours in clinical practice, with a focus on evidence-based practice.
This accelerated course equips experienced AHP clinical supervisors and educators with skills in providing effective clinical training to AHPs and students.
This module explores age-related changes in physiological, physical, and mental aspects.
